questions.stem: Equine laminitis is BEST defined as:

options.label: A
options.text: Inflammation of the digital flexor tendons

options.label: B
options.text: Inflammation and failure of the lamellar interface between the hoof wall and the distal phalanx (P3)

options.label: C
options.text: Degeneration of the navicular bone

options.label: D
options.text: Infection of the coronary band only

questions.explanation: Laminitis is defined as inflammation and failure of the lamellar interface between the hoof wall and P3, resulting in loss of support. It is not tendonitis, navicular disease, or coronary band infection (A, C, D).

questions.stem: The structural consequence of laminitis within the hoof capsule is:

options.label: A
options.text: Luxation of the fetlock joint

options.label: B
options.text: Rotation and/or sinking of the distal phalanx (P3)

options.label: C
options.text: Fracture of the sesamoid bones

options.label: D
options.text: Dislocation of the coffin joint

questions.explanation: Structural failure leads to rotation and/or sinking of the distal phalanx within the hoof capsule, causing profound pain and deformity. Fetlock luxation, sesamoid fractures, or coffin joint dislocation (A, C, D) are different pathologies.

questions.stem: Which horses are MOST predisposed to laminitis based on epidemiology?

options.label: A
options.text: Only young racehorses in training

options.label: B
options.text: Ponies and obese horses, especially certain native and easy‑keeper breeds

options.label: C
options.text: Only geriatric Thoroughbreds

options.label: D
options.text: Only broodmares in late gestation

questions.explanation: Laminitis can occur in all breeds, but ponies and obese horses, especially easy‑keeper/native breeds, are particularly predisposed. It is not restricted to young racehorses, geriatrics, or broodmares (A, C, D).

questions.stem: Predisposed breeds mentioned for laminitis include:

options.label: A
options.text: Arabians, Morgans, native ponies, and Paso Finos

options.label: B
options.text: Greyhounds and Bulldogs

options.label: C
options.text: Holstein cattle and sheep

options.label: D
options.text: Only draft horses

questions.explanation: Predisposed breeds mentioned include native ponies, Morgans, Arabians, and Paso Finos, which often have thrifty metabolisms and obesity tendencies. The other species/breeds listed (B–D) are incorrect.

questions.stem: At the cellular level, laminitis involves:

options.label: A
options.text: Strengthening of lamellar basal epithelial cells

options.label: B
options.text: Disruption of lamellar basal epithelial cells and loss of attachment to the basement membrane

options.label: C
options.text: Increased production of hoof horn only

options.label: D
options.text: Hyperplasia of coronary corium

questions.explanation: Laminitis involves disruption of lamellar basal epithelial cells and loss of their attachment to the basement membrane, compromising the suspensory apparatus of P3. Strengthening or hyperplasia (A, C, D) does not occur.

questions.stem: In sepsis‑related laminitis (SRL), the primary pathophysiologic mechanism is:

options.label: A
options.text: Local trauma to the hoof alone

options.label: B
options.text: Systemic inflammation leading to lamellar ischemia and damage

options.label: C
options.text: Purely mechanical overload of the limb

options.label: D
options.text: Vitamin C deficiency

questions.explanation: In sepsis‑related laminitis, systemic inflammatory mediators and endotoxins cause lamellar ischemia and metabolic dysfunction. Local trauma alone, mechanical overload, or vitamin deficiency (A, C, D) are not the main mechanisms.

questions.stem: Endocrinopathic laminitis (sometimes termed EMS‑associated laminitis) is primarily linked to:

options.label: A
options.text: Hypoglycemia

options.label: B
options.text: Insulin dysregulation and hyperinsulinemia causing metabolic failure in lamellar cells

options.label: C
options.text: Bacterial infection of the hoof wall

options.label: D
options.text: Primary navicular disease

questions.explanation: Endocrinopathic laminitis is closely linked to insulin dysregulation/hyperinsulinemia, as seen in EMS or PPID, leading to lamellar metabolic failure. Hypoglycemia, infection, or navicular disease (A, C, D) do not define this form.

questions.stem: Supporting‑limb laminitis (SLL) usually develops:

options.label: A
options.text: In all four limbs simultaneously

options.label: B
options.text: In the limb contralateral to an injured or immobilized limb due to prolonged weight bearing and ischemia

options.label: C
options.text: Only in the forelimbs of racehorses

options.label: D
options.text: Only in horses on pasture

questions.explanation: Supporting‑limb laminitis occurs in the limb opposite an injured one due to prolonged weight bearing and compromised perfusion. It is not typically all limbs, forelimbs of racehorses only, or pasture‑specific (A, C, D).

questions.stem: Early clinical signs of laminitis in the acute phase include:

options.label: A
options.text: Severe coughing and nasal discharge

options.label: B
options.text: Reluctance to move, “sawhorse stance,” warm hoof walls, bounding digital pulses, and shifting weight

options.label: C
options.text: Generalized muscle atrophy and head tilt

options.label: D
options.text: Colic with diarrhea

questions.explanation: Early signs include reluctance to move, sawhorse stance, warm hoof walls, bounding digital pulses, and shifting weight off painful feet. Respiratory or neurologic signs (A, C, D) do not characterize laminitis.

questions.stem: Chronic laminitis may be characterized by:

options.label: A
options.text: Convex or dropped sole, hoof rings, a “dropped” coronary band, and “Aladdin’s slipper” hoof deformity

options.label: B
options.text: Normal hoof shape with no external changes

options.label: C
options.text: Only mild heel cracks

options.label: D
options.text: Sole bruising without hoof capsule distortion

questions.explanation: Chronic laminitis shows a convex (“dropped”) sole, hoof rings, a dropped coronary band, and “Aladdin’s slipper” deformity of the hoof. Normal hooves or minor cracks (B–D) miss these classic changes.

questions.stem: Which of the following is NOT listed as a systemic differential diagnosis that can mimic laminitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Tetanus

options.label: B
options.text: Rabies

options.label: C
options.text: Myopathy

options.label: D
options.text: Equine motor neuron disease

questions.stem: Foot‑related conditions that can mimic laminitis include:

options.label: A
options.text: Hoof abscess, P3 fracture, navicular disease, sole bruising, and white line disease

options.label: B
options.text: Colitis and metritis

options.label: C
options.text: Pleuritis and pneumonia

options.label: D
options.text: Gastric ulcer disease

questions.explanation: Hoof abscess, P3 fracture, navicular disease, sole bruising, and white line disease are important foot‑related differentials for laminitis‑like pain. Colitis, pleuritis, and gastric ulcers (B–D) are systemic or extra‑foot disorders.

questions.stem: A key physical examination finding supporting laminitis includes:

options.label: A
options.text: Cold hoof wall with absent digital pulses

options.label: B
options.text: Heat in the hoof capsule and a bounding digital pulse

options.label: C
options.text: Generalized skin tenting and dehydration only

options.label: D
options.text: Enlarged submandibular lymph nodes

questions.explanation: A warm hoof wall and a bounding digital pulse are hallmark findings suggesting active laminitis. Cold hooves (A) or unrelated systemic signs (C, D) are less specific.

questions.stem: Radiography in laminitis is primarily used to:

options.label: A
options.text: Identify lung metastases

options.label: B
options.text: Detect rotation or sinking of P3 relative to the hoof wall

options.label: C
options.text: Diagnose fractures of the scapula

options.label: D
options.text: Assess dental abnormalities

questions.explanation: Radiographs are used to assess rotation and/or sinking of P3 relative to the hoof capsule, guide trimming/shoeing, and monitor progression. The other options (A, C, D) refer to unrelated uses of radiography.

questions.stem: Endocrine testing in laminitis work‑ups is particularly important for detecting:

options.label: A
options.text: Hypoadrenocorticism

options.label: B
options.text: Equine metabolic syndrome (EMS) and pituitary pars intermedia dysfunction (PPID) via insulin and ACTH testing

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperthyroidism

options.label: D
options.text: Primary hypocalcemia

questions.explanation: Endocrine testing for insulin and ACTH helps detect EMS and PPID, key contributors to endocrinopathic laminitis. Adrenal, thyroid, or calcium abnormalities (A, C, D) are not primary targets here.

questions.stem: Sepsis‑related laminitis (SRL) is typically associated with underlying conditions such as:

options.label: A
options.text: Gastric ulcers only

options.label: B
options.text: Colitis, metritis, retained placenta, or pleuropneumonia

options.label: C
options.text: Osteoarthritis

options.label: D
options.text: Hepatic encephalopathy

questions.explanation: Sepsis‑related laminitis is commonly associated with systemic inflammatory diseases such as colitis, metritis, retained placenta, and pleuropneumonia. Osteoarthritis or hepatic encephalopathy (C, D) do not primarily drive SRL.

questions.stem: Major therapeutic objectives in treating laminitis are to:

options.label: A
options.text: Increase exercise and remove all analgesia

options.label: B
options.text: Control pain, limit further lamellar damage, and restore hoof stability

options.label: C
options.text: Focus only on correcting endocrine tests

options.label: D
options.text: Avoid any mechanical support

questions.explanation: Treatment aims to control pain, limit additional lamellar injury, and restore hoof stability via multimodal therapy. Increasing exercise or avoiding mechanical support (A, C, D) would worsen the condition.

questions.stem: NSAIDs are considered the cornerstone of laminitis pain management. Commonly used NSAIDs in horses include:

options.label: A
options.text: Phenylbutazone, flunixin meglumine, and firocoxib

options.label: B
options.text: Aspirin and acetaminophen only

options.label: C
options.text: Meloxicam in cats

options.label: D
options.text: Only topical anti‑inflammatories

questions.explanation: Phenylbutazone, flunixin meglumine, and firocoxib are commonly used NSAIDs for laminitis pain control in horses. Aspirin, acetaminophen, or species‑inappropriate drugs (B–D) are not mainstays.

questions.stem: Adjunct analgesic/anti‑pain options mentioned for severe laminitis include:

options.label: A
options.text: Lidocaine constant rate infusion, α₂‑agonists, gabapentin/pregabalin, and opioids such as butorphanol or morphine

options.label: B
options.text: Only local hoof blocks

options.label: C
options.text: Benzodiazepines alone

options.label: D
options.text: Antihistamines only

questions.explanation: Adjunct options include lidocaine CRI, α₂‑agonists (e.g., xylazine), gabapentin/pregabalin for neuropathic pain, and opioids such as butorphanol or morphine in severe cases. Local blocks alone or unrelated drug classes (B–D) are insufficient.

questions.stem: Mechanical and supportive therapies in laminitis commonly include:

options.label: A
options.text: Keeping the horse on hard concrete to harden the hoof

options.label: B
options.text: Frog and sole support (foam pads, impression material, deep bedding) plus corrective trimming/shoeing to realign P3 and distribute load

options.label: C
options.text: Removing all bedding to visualize hooves clearly

options.label: D
options.text: Casting the limb to prevent any movement

questions.explanation: Mechanical support strategies include frog/sole support with pads, impression materials, deep bedding, and corrective trimming/shoeing to realign P3 and redistribute weight. Hard flooring, no bedding, or casting (A, C, D) can exacerbate pain and damage.

questions.stem: Digital cryotherapy (continuous icing of the feet) is MOST beneficial when applied:

options.label: A
options.text: Only after chronic hoof deformity develops

options.label: B
options.text: During the sepsis phase and early laminitis to reduce lamellar damage

options.label: C
options.text: After the horse has fully recovered

options.label: D
options.text: To the hindlimbs only, regardless of lesion location

questions.explanation: Continuous digital cryotherapy during the early sepsis/laminitis phase helps reduce lamellar inflammation and structural damage; it is a proven preventive/early intervention. Starting only after chronic deformity (A) or after recovery (C) is too late.

questions.stem: Deep digital flexor tenotomy in laminitis management is:

options.label: A
options.text: A first‑line treatment for all mild cases

options.label: B
options.text: A salvage procedure for refractory chronic cases with severe rotation

options.label: C
options.text: Contraindicated in all horses

options.label: D
options.text: Only used in foals

questions.explanation: Deep digital flexor tenotomy is a salvage procedure for refractory chronic cases with severe rotation to reduce tension on P3. It is not first‑line, universally contraindicated, or foal‑specific (A, C, D).

questions.stem: Key preventive measures to reduce laminitis risk include:

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing nonstructural carbohydrates and using high‑dose corticosteroids when possible

options.label: B
options.text: Controlling diet (limiting NSC), managing weight and exercise, treating endocrine disorders (PPID, EMS), and avoiding unnecessary high‑dose corticosteroids

options.label: C
options.text: Keeping horses stall‑confined with no exercise

options.label: D
options.text: Feeding ad libitum grain with minimal forage

questions.explanation: Prevention focuses on controlling NSC intake, maintaining proper weight and exercise, managing endocrine diseases, and avoiding unnecessary high‑dose corticosteroids. The other options (A, C, D) increase laminitis risk.

questions.stem: Prognosis for laminitis is MOST favorable when:

options.label: A
options.text: P3 has sunk and multiple limbs are involved

options.label: B
options.text: There is no rotation, mild disease, and no significant systemic illness

options.label: C
options.text: The laminitis is supporting‑limb in a heavy draft horse

options.label: D
options.text: The horse has repeated severe episodes

questions.explanation: Prognosis is best in mild cases without rotation or significant systemic disease; early detection and management improve outcomes. Sinking P3, multiple limbs, or repeated severe bouts (A, C, D) worsen prognosis.

questions.stem: In general, the prognosis for severe laminitis with P3 sinking or multiple limbs affected is:

options.label: A
options.text: Excellent, with most horses returning to full athletic function

options.label: B
options.text: Guarded to poor, and many survivors may not return to prior athletic use

options.label: C
options.text: Always fatal

options.label: D
options.text: Unrelated to severity or number of limbs affected

questions.explanation: Severe laminitis with P3 sinking or multiple limbs affected carries a guarded to poor prognosis; many survivors do not return to previous athletic performance. It is not uniformly excellent or fatal (A, C) and is clearly related to severity and limb involvement (D).
